zerver_message.subject: intros
zerver_message.content: Hi! I am Jaan. I am teaching this course and through the data thinking principles we will learn together I hope to help people feel more self-efficacy and agency in an era where much of the forces that shape our behavior, information consumption, political decisions, financial decisions and resources are hidden in closed-source artificial intelligence technology.
zerver_message.rendered_content: Hi! I am Jaan. I am teaching this course and through the data thinking principles we will learn together I hope to help people feel more self-efficacy and agency in an era where much of the forces that shape our behavior, information consumption, political decisions, financial decisions and resources are hidden in closed-source artificial intelligence technology.

zerver_message.subject: intros
zerver_message.content:
Hello Jaan,
I am Nesma, a Ph.D. student at the University of Tartu.
I understood from the description in OIS that the course will not focus on specific methods, but the idea is to put them all together. So I look forward to acquiring hands-on experience solving real-world problems with appropriate data analysis methods and learning about the best practices for designing effective solutions. Additionally, I look forward to gaining data visualization and storytelling skills, enabling me to communicate data findings more effectively to stakeholders. Furthermore, exploring emerging trends and innovations in the field of data science as the ChatGPT :).

zerver_message.subject: intros
zerver_message.content: Hi, I'm Uku. I'm a research software engineer@ UT ICS. I have some prior interest in NLP and I'm very excited about how easily GPT seems to solve the hard engineering problems we were working on only ~5 years ago.  I'm confident that this is a revolutionary step in data analysis and I'm interested in hearing others' thoughts on these emerging technologies.

zerver_message.subject: intros
zerver_message.content: Hi, I am Antti, working (0.25; that is, part time) at Sandbox, Institute of Computer Science, U of Tartu . I am very interested to how and why data thinking connects to what is in and around Sandbox called design thinking . I also work at Aalto University in Finland on several projects on AI ( AI4Europe for the Commission, AIXCon for Business Finland) in which both ChatGPT is an interesting recent development. So, this course you have set up seems very interesting !

thank you so much rustam! 

this is very helpful feedback. 

is the following easier to understand?

objectives:
```quote
The objective of the course is to teach the fundamental
concepts in data science, artificial intelligence, natural language
processing, and causal inference in the service of data analysis,
visualization, communication, and decision-making based on
inferences. This course will empower you to take on the world
using these powerful tools.
```

learning outcomes: 
```quote
● You will create and publish a report using the help of
ChatGPT for the data thinking course blog related to a
dataset you need to use to make a decision about your
life; you will defend this report through a presentation.
● The report you create will demonstrate your ability to
apply the principles of data thinking, such as identifying
research questions and testing your hypotheses
regarding the data you have collected, cleaned,
analyzed, and visualized.
● The interactive component of the report will include a
deployed machine learning model that helps someone
make a decision based on the data thinking principles
you select as most helpful.
● You will critique, defend, appraise the use of data
thinking in domains such as economics, health care, life
sciences, pharmaceuticals, climate change, real estate,
finance, and science.
● You will find, analyze, and report your findings on
public datasets or datasets you collect, curate, or create.
● You will use version control systems such as Git and
GitHub, Data Version Control, Google Colaboratory
Notebooks, Jupyter Notebooks, LaTeX, Visual Studio
Code, Copilot, ChatGPT.
● You will differentiate between appropriate methods and
the pros and cons of using each depending on the scale,
level of structure, source, and issues in specific datasets
both large and small.
● You will describe and define key terms and concepts
related to the principles of data thinking, machine
learning and artificial intelligence, statistics, causal
inference, natural language processing, and large
language models.
● You will review your classmate’s code and provide
constructive feedback on code style, code quality, and
best practices in the principles of data thinking.
● You will classify, discuss, summarize, and explain key
concepts of data thinking
```

let me know if that helps and i will revise it accordingly!

zerver_message.subject: intros
zerver_message.content: Hi everyone, my name is Nikolai, and I'm a PhD student in Philosophy at UT. My research has recently shifted towards experimental philosophy, where we mainly conduct surveys and corpus analyses to test philosophical theories, similar to social scientists. I'm interested in gaining a better understanding of crucial data science concepts during this course, and I hope to see how tools like ChatGPT (or Bard) can benefit my research. I have some experience with Python, R, and statistics, and I'm looking forward to learning more!

zerver_message.subject: main
zerver_message.content:
@_**Kaarel Kaarelson|591047** [said](https://datathinking.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/345278-general/topic/main/near/329296225):
```quote
1) I'm taking a course called [Artificial Intelligence](https://ois2.ut.ee/#/courses/LTAT.01.003/version/67a5a324-87cc-c40e-7cd5-80b05ab18d0f/details), how does this course differ from it? Are we using ChatGPT just as an add-on?
```
great question! it looks like that course is in estonian, and this data thinking course is in english. 

it is unfortunate -- because my mother tongue is estonian -- but the fact is that many terms in computer science and machine learning are difficult to translate. for example, chatGPT, deep learning, AI, etc, so i find computer science research in estonian more confusing than in english where these words originate, especially for newer research. 

for example when i gave a talk at north star AI (a conference in tallinn) a few years ago, i tried to introduce these concepts in estonian: masinõppe ja tehisintellekt pilves, võrgustikku trenn graafiku töötelmismasinatega, jne. 

so i think the best approach may be to decide what languages you hope to work in, read research papers in, etc. 

the topics are probably the same, but broader coverage or emphasis of reinforcement learning or computer vision seems likely for LTAT.01.003 versus data thinking. i hope to go more in-depth on ethics in AI (e.g. people in kenya getting paid little money to train ChatGPT), and also teach the underlying statistics, mathematics, and programming needed to build chatGPT yourself. 

does that help? let me know if you have any remaining questions!

for example when i gave a talk at north star AI (a conference in tallinn) a few years ago, i tried to introduce these concepts in estonian: masinõppe ja tehisintellekt pilves, võrgustikku trenn graafiku töötelmismasinatega, jne.

does that help? let me know if you have any remaining questions!

zerver_message.subject: main
zerver_message.content:
@_**Kaarel Kaarelson|591047** [said](https://datathinking.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/345278-general/topic/main/near/329296225):
```quote
2) Why is the objective to publish the final reports to One Fact Foundation website, the non-profit you're co-founder of? Why not publish it to Medium or Towards Data Science blog?
```
this is because of legal and technical reasons. 

legally, the course is creative commons with recordings livestreamed on https://www.twitch.tv/onefactfoundation (not the zoom call, only my audio and video; by law, no student faces can be shown and the twitch interface through an app called OBS can't even access the zoom app; setup is here: https://github.com/onefact/datathinking.org/issues/16). 

this is because my salary is paid by the university of pennsylvania and by university of tartu, and one way to work across institutions in this manner that cannot hire me full-time as a tenured professor is to share resources. 

further, to ensure that other students benefit and the course improves over time, the content is creative commons licensed (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0/legalcode) and software is apache 2.0 licensed (https://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0). 

this ensures that the most people around the world who can't afford education, chatgpt, or other such tools can still get access to the material.

similarly, there is a paywall at towards data science and medium, which prevents people from reading it if they can't afford subscriptions or do not want their data harvested by these privately-run, for-profit companies. 

however, students are free to publish anywhere -- the creative commons means content can be adapted and re-used for any purpose! :) 

another technical reason is that tools like `altair`, `latex`, `duckdb`, `apache arrow`, and others are supported by next.js (how we build the website, https://github.com/onefact/datathinking.org/), which means students can benefit from learning to use these tools and processes. but a tool like medium or towards data science prohibits use of these things which makes it quite complicated to publish interactive data analyses and data thinking processess

hope this helps! let me know if you have any remaining questions about this -- excellent questions, and you are doing the data thinking, data detective process already!

zerver_message.subject: plotting
zerver_message.content:
[img.png](/user_uploads/47304/FPXoM0fTZl4BWtWe3dCS6E4K/img.png)

**Data is random** 

**code is here look for raw text ** 

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

# Define the sales data as a numpy array
sales_data = np.array([[1000, 800, 1200, 1500, 2000, 2500, 3000, 3500, 3000, 2500, 2000, 1500]])

# Add a row of random losses from fraud using the numpy random function
fraud_losses = np.random.randint(0, 1000, (1, 12))
sales_data = np.append(sales_data, fraud_losses, axis=0)

# Define the x-axis labels as the months
months = ['Jan', 'Feb', 'Mar', 'Apr', 'May', 'Jun', 'Jul', 'Aug', 'Sep', 'Oct', 'Nov', 'Dec']

# Create a line plot with the sales data and fraud losses
plt.plot(months, sales_data[0], label='Sales')
plt.plot(months, sales_data[1], label='Losses from Fraud')

# Set the plot title, labels, and legend
plt.title('Sales Data with Fraud Losses')
plt.xlabel('Months')
plt.ylabel('Dollars')
plt.legend()

# Show the plot
plt.show()

Sure, I can help you with that! Here's a simple Python program using the pandas and matplotlib libraries to read in the data from "Mineral_Database.csv" and create a scatter plot of Mohs Hardness vs Specific Gravity:

```
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load data from CSV file
df = pd.read_csv('Mineral_Database.csv')

# Extract relevant columns
mohs_hardness = df['Mohs Hardness']
specific_gravity = df['Specific Gravity']

# Create scatter plot
plt.scatter(specific_gravity, mohs_hardness)
plt.xlabel('Specific Gravity')
plt.ylabel('Mohs Hardness')
plt.title('Mohs Hardness vs Specific Gravity')

# Show plot
plt.show()
```
```quote

zerver_message.subject: intros
zerver_message.content:
Heya everyone! Sorry for the late reply.
I'm a Data Science masters student at Tartu University.

I'm kind of in-between about declaring this course or not.
I'm doing and defending  my thesis this semester and I just had a child few days ago. I'm also working full time as a Data engineer with various health data at a governmental IT-house. Hence I have this question: Can I do this course just for myself without having to declare anything? I do not want to be at point later where I just do not have the time to do the required project/exam and I get not passed on my final marks.

Besides that I'm very interested about how I could utilize chatgpt effectively at various aspects of my life, for example:
1) as a Data engineer, data scientist 
2) with my masters thesis
3) anything I want to research and learn about

How to systematically utilize chatgpt for Maximum benefit? By that I do not mean to get a copy-paste answers to ones questions, but to actually learn from the answers. 
-Is there a kind of blueprint one could follow when working with chatgpt? How would that look like?
-no technology is perfect. What are chatgpts shortcomings we should be aware of?
- chatgpt is gonna change the world alot! Theres probably going to be a myriad of so called "experts" who  actually know nothing about the subject wouldn't it be for the help of chatgpt. How should we handle this kind of world?
I could go on but I'm gonna draw a line here.

I appreciate the initiative alot and find it to be a very crucial course, hence also why I find it so important to do it at my own pace.
BR!
Rasmus

Sure, I guess my data file was not following the correct path, so I had to change the path of the file. I did this by first copying the path of my data file (by clicking on the file name and then right click) then I asked ChatGPT what to do next. It said I should use command **"cd"** and the name of the file path I have just copied, so for me it was the code - cd /workspaces/datathinking.org-codespace/data/
Then I had to write the code - ls Minerals_Database.csv using the command **"ls"** so make sure that the file exists and then I plotted the code you and ChatGPT gave me - 
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load data from CSV file
df = pd.read_csv('Minerals_Database.csv')

# Extract relevant columns
mohs_hardness = df['Mohs Hardness']
specific_gravity = df['Specific Gravity']

# Create scatter plot
plt.scatter(specific_gravity, mohs_hardness)
plt.xlabel('Specific Gravity')
plt.ylabel('Mohs Hardness')
plt.title('Mohs Hardness vs Specific Gravity')

# Show plot
plt.show()

I am attaching a screenshot of the convo with ChatGPT.

zerver_message.subject: intros
zerver_message.content:
Hello. My name is Tim. I am an ethnographer - I study humans and their in their natural habitats -   and I am a designer - I make the plans and specifications for the building of things (and non-things) ... a lot of 'non-things' in recent years, as I have been working with service/experience and other strategic and holistic design approaches. I started out as a graphic designer and printer/setter (photo-mechanical) and over the years worked in interaction design, animation, advertising, digital, and ... I love bicycles and sushi. I am a polyglot.   I'm learning to oil paint. My favourite number is 42. A good book I like is: THHGTTG.  

Very happy to be part of this course! I look forward to learning some of the maths behind all this AL/ML stuff!

zerver_message.content:
Hello everyone,

I recently analyzed the IMDb Movies Dataset (https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/rajugc/imdb-movies-dataset-based-on-genre) and focused specifically on action movies. With the help of ChatGPT, I generated an interactive plot that displays the relationship between Movie Rating and Gross Box Office.

However, due to missing data for some movies in the dataset, the Gross Box Office data may not be very reliable. Nonetheless, the plot still provides an interesting and engaging visualization: [Figure_1-gpt.png](/user_uploads/47304/KH2uA9TUEwMNvrdncatDbOHK/Figure_1-gpt.png) [Figure_2-gpt.png](/user_uploads/47304/WaGz0O68BtSuZCNX05UoaPyS/Figure_2-gpt.png) [Figure_3-gpt.png](/user_uploads/47304/NLbNo_z-KsFueJo_nm2xZhN3/Figure_3-gpt.png) [Figure_4-gpt.png](/user_uploads/47304/_XSnr6cQI4mAv9M5zMA5jhRT/Figure_4-gpt.png)

zerver_message.content: Hi! My name is Robyn and I also study Bioengineering MSc in Tartu. I did my bachelor's in material science, where we did extensive higher maths courses, some java and python. I am very intrigued by the state of AI and it's instant open source use and how it will affect the society as a whole in a few years, and I hope this course gives me some insight into what's to come  and maybe some skills to not maybe be ahead of the curve but at least not too behind.

zerver_message.content:
hi @**everyone** ! just emailed everyone the link to the latest lecture recording. 

the example we did in class for the plan to do logistic regression is in the example data thinking codespace: https://github.com/onefact/datathinking.org-codespace/blob/main/notebooks/230227-logistic-regression-example-on-iris-dataset.ipynb 

please let me know if you didn't get the email or have any questions! it is exciting to get to co-create this material, so please continue asking when you are stuck and sharing resources in the chat as you are doing. 

the visualizations you are already making are awesome!!! and the experience reports!!!! 

for context, it took me many years to learn these skills and i have not taken a formal computer science class. so if it's hard for you, it was very hard for me and it's normal to ask for a lot of help or need a lot of guidance from humans or ChatGPT. 

here's a helpful link for describing the unix shell (https://missing.csail.mit.edu/2020/course-shell/) which will help with codespaces and stuff. 

see you soon!

zerver_message.subject: plotting
zerver_message.content:
I used my own data (bacterial composition of human gut for 2400 people from Estonian population). 
[plot.png](/user_uploads/47304/WUTICPghlJCXs5kgwcX0FMkB/plot.png) 

First I wrote the code myself and then I asked chatGTP to improve my code. Here is the suggestions and my comments:

1. Instead of assigning the colors to a list, you can use the built-in color maps in Matplotlib, such as 'tab10', 'tab20', or 'Pastel1'. This can simplify your code and ensure better color contrast.
- I disagree, I did it on purpose because I don't like standard palettes.
 
2. You are reassigning the plt variable, which is not recommended as it overwrites the default plt module. Instead, you can use a different variable name, such as ax.
- Okay, maybe that's better.

3. Since you're importing pyplot twice, it's better to just import it once at the beginning of your code.
- It's true, I didn't notice it.
[code1.png](/user_uploads/47304/oPU4UeT5v0_9m5_VcMUHjkPS/code1.png)
zerver_message.rendered_content:

  1. Instead of assigning the colors to a list, you can use the built-in color maps in Matplotlib, such as 'tab10', 'tab20', or 'Pastel1'. This can simplify your code and ensure better color contrast.
  • I disagree, I did it on purpose because I don't like standard palettes.
  1. You are reassigning the plt variable, which is not recommended as it overwrites the default plt module. Instead, you can use a different variable name, such as ax.
  • Okay, maybe that's better.
  1. Since you're importing pyplot twice, it's better to just import it once at the beginning of your code.
  • It's true, I didn't notice it.

````
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Define some usage statistics for electric cars with Li-ion batteries
car_names = ['Tesla Model S', 'Nissan Leaf', 'Chevrolet Bolt', 'BMW i3', 'Ford Mustang Mach-E']
car_sales = [80000, 140000, 50000, 30000, 25000]
car_ranges = [400, 150, 259, 153, 270]

# Create a bar chart of car sales
fig, ax = plt.subplots()
ax.bar(car_names, car_sales)
ax.set_ylabel('Sales')
ax.set_title('Usage Statistics of Electric Cars with Li-ion Batteries')
plt.xticks(rotation=45)

# Create a line chart of car ranges
fig2, ax2 = plt.subplots()
ax2.plot(car_names, car_ranges, marker='o')
ax2.set_ylabel('Range (miles)')
ax2.set_title('Usage Statistics of Electric Cars with Li-ion Batteries')
plt.xticks(rotation=45)

plt.show()

zerver_message.content:
hi all! if you're curious, here is where i got stuck after class. i had to email github's support team for help. (sharing because i think it helps to align on style guide and best practices, such as the reading in the intro class)

Hi! I'm teaching datathinking.org, an open source course at several schools. There are over 100 students and this is a severe blocker (I might be naïve and missing something basic here!).

I teach using github codespaces, and it is AMAZING (thank you!).

However, I can't commit to this repository: https://github.com/onefact/datathinking.org-codespace

What I do right now:
- use a personal account to teach in class (https://github.com/altosaar/datathinking.org-codespace)
- use the below code to transfer changes from this code to the main data thinking codespace

Is there a better way? 

Grateful for any help! Thank you so, so much for making this -- the students are not dependent on Colab (which is harder to afford GPUs on in Estonia, and other non-Western contexts the course is aimed at).

Jaan

hi all! if you're curious, here is where i got stuck after class. i had to email github's support team for help. (sharing because i think it helps to align on style guide and best practices, such as the reading in the intro class)

Hi! I'm teaching datathinking.org, an open source course at several schools. There are over 100 students and this is a severe blocker (I might be naïve and missing something basic here!).

I teach using github codespaces, and it is AMAZING (thank you!).

However, I can't commit to this repository: https://github.com/onefact/datathinking.org-codespace

What I do right now:

  • use a personal account to teach in class (https://github.com/altosaar/datathinking.org-codespace)
  • use the below code to transfer changes from this code to the main data thinking codespace

Is there a better way?

Grateful for any help! Thank you so, so much for making this -- the students are not dependent on Colab (which is harder to afford GPUs on in Estonia, and other non-Western contexts the course is aimed at).

Jaan

hi @**everyone** ! i just sent out the recording for today's lecture and link to the jupyter notebook. please let me know if you didn't receive it, and feel free to join office hours on wednesday in the [course calendar](https://calendar.google.com/calendar/embed?src=c_328553c1b9528de0dce06cffb83a52dfa0ae4864badbcf7d527f802d8dfa3fde%40group.calendar.google.com&ctz=America%2FNew_York) :)

please review the lecture recording for some key teaching moments: 

* hovering over the definition of a function in visual studio code (in a github codespace) to learn about what a function might do 

* how to prompt github copilot for help figuring out a new concept such as `embeddings` 

* how to debug anaconda environments in visual studio code. 

as always please reach out if you have any questions!!

zerver_message.subject: main
zerver_message.content:
hi all! i'm finally completing the [homework](https://github.com/onefact/datathinking.org/issues/9) :) 

i have some experience with data thinking through teaching this course where we are defining what it is together, and i have done some research in machine learning and artificial intelligence through my graduate school training in computer science & computational physics. through this course i hope to articulate a theory of change for how society will be impacted by technology such as chatgpt, and how we can help learners around the world feel more agency and an internal locus of control when coping with large shifts in behavior, misinformation, and algorithmic advertising and recommender systems at societal & global scale.

zerver_message.subject: plotting
zerver_message.content:
I plot the dependence of the cost of living on the quality of life in different countries. Color marked parts of the world. The graph is interactive, if you move the cursor to the dot, you can see the name of the country.

Quality of Life Index (higher is better) is an estimation of overall quality of life by using an empirical formula which takes into account purchasing power index (higher is better), pollution index (lower is better), house price to income ratio (lower is better), cost of living index (lower is better), safety index (higher is better), health care index (higher is better), traffic commute time index (lower is better) and climate index (higher is better).
These indices are relative to New York City (NYC). Which means that for New York City, each index should be 100(%). If a city has a Cost of Living Index of 120, it means Numbeo has estimated it is 20% more expensive than New York (excluding rent).
data source: https://www.numbeo.com/cost-of-living/

Interactive plot here:
[Cost_vs_quality.html](/user_uploads/47304/0qoO4dslFQkerwzQENRmbwv-/Cost_vs_quality.html)

[Plot_printScreen.png](/user_uploads/47304/XnazT-nor5IrpSizuk3S9nZx/Plot_printScreen.png)

zerver_message.subject: plotting
zerver_message.content:
@_**Nikolai Shurakov|590111** [said](https://datathinking.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/345278-general/topic/plotting/near/338295123):
```quote
Hello everyone,

I recently analyzed the IMDb Movies Dataset (https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/rajugc/imdb-movies-dataset-based-on-genre) and focused specifically on action movies. With the help of ChatGPT, I generated an interactive plot that displays the relationship between Movie Rating and Gross Box Office.

However, due to missing data for some movies in the dataset, the Gross Box Office data may not be very reliable. Nonetheless, the plot still provides an interesting and engaging visualization: [Figure_1-gpt.png](/user_uploads/47304/KH2uA9TUEwMNvrdncatDbOHK/Figure_1-gpt.png) [Figure_2-gpt.png](/user_uploads/47304/WaGz0O68BtSuZCNX05UoaPyS/Figure_2-gpt.png) [Figure_3-gpt.png](/user_uploads/47304/NLbNo_z-KsFueJo_nm2xZhN3/Figure_3-gpt.png) [Figure_4-gpt.png](/user_uploads/47304/_XSnr6cQI4mAv9M5zMA5jhRT/Figure_4-gpt.png)
```
I tried to apply the regression model to the plot I made earlier. I am trying to understand the relationship between the rating of an action film, which is an indicator of its quality (let's assume so), and the gross box office, which is a measure of the total amount of money earned by the film. Based on this analysis, **there is not a strong relationship between these two variables**. The accuracy of the regression model is 37%.

This means that a film's box office success is not necessarily a strong indicator of its quality. It's possible for a movie to do well at the box office even if it's not highly rated by critics or audiences. Similarly, a movie that is highly rated may not necessarily be a box office hit.

It's important to note that correlation does not necessarily imply causation. Just because there is not a strong correlation between a movie's rating and its box office performance, it doesn't mean that one doesn't affect the other in some way. Other factors, such as marketing, budget, and star power, may also play a role in a movie's box office success. [image.png](/user_uploads/47304/57O5TUs1FACd1jXoxH-jZqjl/image.png)

zerver_message.subject: plotting
zerver_message.content:
My first plot was about Covid vaccination in different countries, however, the data I had was not good for applying linear regression to it (you can see screenshot 1). I decided to take a different dataset and chose this one (https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/uciml/red-wine-quality-cortez-et-al-2009), which gives information about wine quality. Things went significantly better, however, the accuracy was about 33% (screenshot 2). I asked chatgpt how I can improve it, and it suggested trying regression (screenshot 3) and feature engineering (screenshot 4). The last approach turned out to be the best and the accuracy was about 64% (twice bigger than in the beginning  ). I think I could make it even higher but I was afraid of overfitting so I decided to leave like that.
[dt_hw2_screenshot1.png](/user_uploads/47304/f5u0ENhHBgixFTIyVtB5bo5N/dt_hw2_screenshot1.png) [dt_hw2_screenshot2.png](/user_uploads/47304/XLkd87j096cGyakNUm2mAeI-/dt_hw2_screenshot2.png) [dt_hw2_screenshot3.png](/user_uploads/47304/hdAX6CxWo49uewFjdgaH0Kv1/dt_hw2_screenshot3.png) [dt_hw2_screenshot4.png](/user_uploads/47304/rodFjs2npj4EwR4djOJiPzkz/dt_hw2_screenshot4.png)
zerver_message.rendered_content:
My first plot was about Covid vaccination in different countries, however, the data I had was not good for applying linear regression to it (you can see screenshot 1). I decided to take a different dataset and chose this one (https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/uciml/red-wine-quality-cortez-et-al-2009), which gives information about wine quality. Things went significantly better, however, the accuracy was about 33% (screenshot 2). I asked chatgpt how I can improve it, and it suggested trying regression (screenshot 3) and feature engineering (screenshot 4). The last approach turned out to be the best and the accuracy was about 64% (twice bigger than in the beginning ). I think I could make it even higher but I was afraid of overfitting so I decided to leave like that.
dt_hw2_screenshot1.png dt_hw2_screenshot2.png dt_hw2_screenshot3.png dt_hw2_screenshot4.png

zerver_message.subject: plotting
zerver_message.content:
Hi, cutting it close this time with the homework :sweat_smile: 

Initially, I tried linear regression with the first homework dataset, but I had my doubts about it as there were only 9 data points. As expected, a linear regression model wasn't accurate, as the data itself was not linearly dependent. ChatGPT suggested trying polynomial regression, so I tried it on the dataset as well. It gave better results, but still, the model wouldn't be that useful in predicting the kind of data I was working on (Apple's total current assets across the years). [image.png](/user_uploads/47304/jiMauaBiDvQ6_k405nXwZnyd/image.png)  

After that, I downloaded a dataset of weather temperatures during WW2 from Kaggle and tried to predict the maximum temperature of the day based on the minimum temperature. As the dependency itself was more linear, and there was a lot more data, the predictions from the linear regression model were a lot better :) [image.png](/user_uploads/47304/-stmWB3T4Yd8JTiM5aJzYPwg/image.png)

zerver_message.subject: main
zerver_message.content:
Hello everyone!

I thought I would share some of my experiences, in case someone else has not thought of this themselves. I have had relatively little exposure to programming in the past. Sometimes the codes that ChatGPT provides as answers can be quite confusing, especially when it comes to resolving the errors. Just the other day, I received the same response four times, saying "Sorry for my mistakes, here's the correct code..." and all four of the "corrected" codes were exactly the same, word by word :smiley:

So I thought about how to handle this better and discovered the following approach. If the first one or two suggested fixes don't work, then:

1.	Go through the code line by line.
2.	Ask for clarification about what (and sometimes also why) you should be checking for as a output result and what code to use, to check it.
3.	Perform the check and give back the result if it’s wrong. If everything is okay, then move on to the next line in the code.
4.	If something goes wrong later on, then it might be necessary to go back to step 2 and check something different.

On one hand, this approach is good because it helps you understand what's going on better. On the other hand, it's also recorded in the ChatGPT log. Sometimes it's been surprising to see how it takes a check made 15-20 steps ago and offers a solution to the next problem based on it. (of course, there are also situations where the absolute complete opposite happens :smiley: )

By following this method, I was able to write a quite long and complex code as part of another subject. I displayed the crimes committed in Tartu over the past 5 years on a map. These crimes were registered using Estonian local location info, so even the conversion was quite a challenge. As a result of the analysis, I found some really interesting entries that would have been missed otherwise. After presenting it, even the lecturer was visibly surprised and asked, "Wow, how did you do that? It seems really-really complicated!" :rolling_on_the_floor_laughing:
zerver_message.rendered_content:
Hello everyone!

I thought I would share some of my experiences, in case someone else has not thought of this themselves. I have had relatively little exposure to programming in the past. Sometimes the codes that ChatGPT provides as answers can be quite confusing, especially when it comes to resolving the errors. Just the other day, I received the same response four times, saying "Sorry for my mistakes, here's the correct code..." and all four of the "corrected" codes were exactly the same, word by word :smiley:

So I thought about how to handle this better and discovered the following approach. If the first one or two suggested fixes don't work, then:

  1. Go through the code line by line.
  2. Ask for clarification about what (and sometimes also why) you should be checking for as a output result and what code to use, to check it.
  3. Perform the check and give back the result if it’s wrong. If everything is okay, then move on to the next line in the code.
  4. If something goes wrong later on, then it might be necessary to go back to step 2 and check something different.

On one hand, this approach is good because it helps you understand what's going on better. On the other hand, it's also recorded in the ChatGPT log. Sometimes it's been surprising to see how it takes a check made 15-20 steps ago and offers a solution to the next problem based on it. (of course, there are also situations where the absolute complete opposite happens :smiley: )

By following this method, I was able to write a quite long and complex code as part of another subject. I displayed the crimes committed in Tartu over the past 5 years on a map. These crimes were registered using Estonian local location info, so even the conversion was quite a challenge. As a result of the analysis, I found some really interesting entries that would have been missed otherwise. After presenting it, even the lecturer was visibly surprised and asked, "Wow, how did you do that? It seems really-really complicated!" :rolling_on_the_floor_laughing:

zerver_message.content:
My graphs and a short novel: [image.png](/user_uploads/47304/Mv4TqPDJ3pJEjDbL3Rnnp2Pf/image.png)  [image.png](/user_uploads/47304/E4I-LOLsLI-4upHHJwpGCGYR/image.png)
I did the visualization of the data I used for the first homework, but it seemed uninteresting.  So here's another completely outrageous and DISCLAIMER!! fabricated graph. The publication data is right but finding comprehensive data on mental illnesses and making it fit the graph was too complicated, I think mostly because I am not really in these fields and chatGPT was unhelpful as it cannot access databases and even the data it has on databases is outdated. A little bit of backstory on this graph is that I was disappointed that GPT4 was released although they said they want to implement a slow release to grow and learn with the people and figure out regulation and so on, but as soon as people get used to the idea that something like this even exists they release an updated version, which I'm guessing was done for the investors. So shortly put this innovation race fueled by an economy built on continuous growth is sometimes tiring. This made me want to prove "Innovation fatigue" on a graph. Even if I had managed this with accurate data it's obviously still oversimplified and making data fit my narrative, which interestingly chatGPT warned me of in every answer. I practically bullied the code out of it . It kept telling me to not make hasty conclusions and not mistake correlation for causation which is positive.

zerver_message.content:
Thank you so much @**Gulnara Yusibova** !! 

Here is the solution it seems:

To publish https://github.com/GulnaraY/codespaces-jupyter/tree/codespace-gulnaray-verbose-journey-r994p5xvvg7c59vv we had to:

1. Go to github.com/codespaces and sign in
2. Click on the three dots beside a code space you created using the data thinking code space template 
3. Click “export to branch”
4. Publish the branch in a repository, go to the settings, scroll to the bottom, and change the visibility of the repository from private to public. 

Does that help?
zerver_message.rendered_content:
Thank you so much @Gulnara Yusibova !!

Here is the solution it seems:

To publish https://github.com/GulnaraY/codespaces-jupyter/tree/codespace-gulnaray-verbose-journey-r994p5xvvg7c59vv we had to:

  1. Go to github.com/codespaces and sign in
  2. Click on the three dots beside a code space you created using the data thinking code space template
  3. Click “export to branch”
  4. Publish the branch in a repository, go to the settings, scroll to the bottom, and change the visibility of the repository from private to public.

Does that help?

zerver_message.subject: intros
zerver_message.content:
Hi! I'm Beni and finally catching up with the lecture! I currently study Computer Science and Philosophy and have a have background in Physics and Ancient Near East.
I was very skeptical of the course, but when I saw how considerate you approached the terrible psychological risks of AI in the jail breaking lecture, I changed my mind! I appreciate very much your effort to softly teach agency and learning in the face of AI. The tech is both wonderful and horrible, amplifying how it is used. In any case it is so important to understand it, its limits, yourself and your relationship, both as an individual and a society! I'm very good at programming, but  still there's much to learn in this course. I'm especially excited about the master class guest lectures!

zerver_message.content:
Details at https://github.com/beijn/datathinking.org-codespace/blob/main/homeworks/230202-plot.ipynb 

[gdp-ef.svg](/user_uploads/47304/AgNB1FWfPefQqtazLj3k3KzF/gdp-ef.svg)
Countries like Mongolia and Turkmenistan (upper left) show that econmic growth can be more or less harmfull to the environment - it depends on the way of growth, which is determined by national policies and global market constrains. Qatar (upper right) shows that it is possible to 'degrow' while still increasing the environmental impact! Singapor, Luxembourg (right) and other northest European countrie showup with growth while reducing footprint. This is a sign of hope, but should be taken with care, as these countries historically contributed the most and now profit from externalization effects. But for most economies, especially in South Asia, economic growth is proportional to environmental destruction. Besides the most African countries all economies by far surpass the maximum sustainable footprint per person.
Data from happyplanetindex.org. Red line number approximate from footprintnetwork.org (state of 2014!). 
[gdp-hpi.svg](/user_uploads/47304/6s6cumo5WSrwFIHNJPz99t57/gdp-hpi.svg) [ef-hpi.svg](/user_uploads/47304/NmPeOoUG-hAEo7E8WK9BP2p-/ef-hpi.svg)

zerver_message.subject: main
zerver_message.content:
@**everyone** in case it is unclear from last class: the content of the homework matters less than the doing of it. that is because the grade depends more on your ability to do things versus your ability to make careful analyses at this stage. 

(this is in the spirit of full transparency for those who don't watch the recording from yesterday where we went over this in detail and highlighted some plots that were very complicated and some plots that used random data!)

the goal is to get in the habit of doing stuff, and one of the principles behind this is exposure therapy. exposed to a stressful stimulus (verbal events such as the words 'difficult, long, tough, frustrating, scary' coming to mind when you think of homework), an emotional response can result. but the magnitude, valence, and frequency of this emotional response can be extinguished through repeated exposure to the original stimulus. this is a normal process that our brains support -- for example, if someone has arachnophobia, they might choose to expose themselves to only thinking about a spider, then seeing if they can handle it. 

then they might see pictures of spiders. then they might have a plastic spider. their brain does not have much choice but to get used to the stressful stimulus (the spider) and the strength of the emotional response (fear) can be extinguished by repeat exposure in safe environments.

part of the process for this course is self-monitoring (we went over this yesterday). noting the intensity of an emotional response to verbal events associated with things like homework or the doing of things. 

you can see that this is mechanical sometimes: posting a linkedin.com link can be scary the first time, but now it's normal. speaking up in class is a behavior we can train and encourage in each other, and especially through role models like @**Gulnara Yusibova|589761** who are strong and @**Indrek Romet** who are strong advocates for themselves.

hope this helps for more context on what's up as we continue :) feedback is always welcomed just dm me or set up a time to chat. i'm always curious to hear about your emotional and practical journeys through data thinking and life!!!

zerver_message.subject: plotting
zerver_message.content:
@**Jaan Altosaar** Hi. I try to filter the raw data with this code below. But what funny is there is no data left in filtered messages file.. And If I wouldn`t filter any data, then there is huge discrepancy between columns that can`t apply logistic regression to it. So, could u pls tell me what to correct the code below, where I do mistake when filtering, it is sth that idk what to keep while filtering.

import json

# Load the data from the 'zulip.json' file
with open('/workspaces/codespaces-jupyter/data/zulipchatraw.json', 'r') as f:
    data = json.load(f)

# Extract the set of valid message IDs from the 'zerver_usermessage' data
valid_ids = set(user_message['id'] for user_message in data['zerver_usermessage'])

# Filter out the invalid messages from the 'zerver_message' data
valid_messages = []
for message in data['zerver_message']:
    if message['id'] in valid_ids and message['content'] != "":
        valid_messages.append(message)

# Write the filtered messages to a new file 'filtered_zulip.json'
with open('filtered_zulip.json', 'w') as f:
    json.dump(valid_messages, f)

Filter out the invalid messages from the 'zerver_message' data

valid_messages = []
for message in data['zerver_message']:
if message['id'] in valid_ids and message['content'] != "":
valid_messages.append(message)

Write the filtered messages to a new file 'filtered_zulip.json'

zerver_message.subject: plotting
zerver_message.content:
@_**Gulnara Yusibova|589761** [said](https://datathinking.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/345278-general/topic/plotting/near/346432363):
```quote
@**Jaan Altosaar** Hi. I try to filter the raw data with this code below. But what funny is there is no data left in filtered messages file.. And If I wouldn`t filter any data, then there is huge discrepancy between columns that can`t apply logistic regression to it. So, could u pls tell me what to correct the code below, where I do mistake when filtering, it is sth that idk what to keep while filtering.

import json

# Load the data from the 'zulip.json' file
with open('/workspaces/codespaces-jupyter/data/zulipchatraw.json', 'r') as f:
    data = json.load(f)

# Extract the set of valid message IDs from the 'zerver_usermessage' data
valid_ids = set(user_message['id'] for user_message in data['zerver_usermessage'])

# Filter out the invalid messages from the 'zerver_message' data
valid_messages = []
for message in data['zerver_message']:
    if message['id'] in valid_ids and message['content'] != "":
        valid_messages.append(message)

# Write the filtered messages to a new file 'filtered_zulip.json'
with open('filtered_zulip.json', 'w') as f:
    json.dump(valid_messages, f)
```

Until this problem happen everything was going well. I was talking to chatgpt to tell me steps even error happens, and it was working very smoothly. But at this point it seems that I should understand my data in json file that I can figure out what to ask from chatgpt, to filter what

My report can be found here: https://github.com/onefact/datathinking.org/issues/119#issuecomment-1494278163

My favourite plot is this one with my attempt to plot a decision boundary of the logistic regression model: [wrong_chart.png](/user_uploads/47304/963hiyUnwLxZt5HqdQqPX5G-/wrong_chart.png). It's my favourite because it's wrong, but for me personally working on it was the moment when I felt that I was starting to understand data thinking. Failing, trying to use chatGPT and documentation, failing again, thinking again, changing something and iteratively coming closer to the goal was absolutely satisfying, even though the final result is not that useful

zerver_message.content:
My report: https://github.com/onefact/datathinking.org/files/11171767/datathinking_org_latex_report_Helena.pdf
It took me a while to complete the report, as I had some difficulties with the first task and had to learn LaTeX. Overall, the report looks okay, but I'm not sure how useful those plots really are, scientifically.
My favorite visualization  is the t-SNE 3D plot of word embeddings, which shows real data from our chat data (including words like "ChatGPT", "code", and "Gulnara"). I also include here a barplot of coefficients of linreg embedding dimensions, but I don't fully understand its logic.
[tsneplot.png](/user_uploads/47304/JUBgdue6xNqBfdYSPTodpBtR/tsneplot.png)

Hey. I made these 3 plots below (logistic reg., linear reg., and embedding, accordingly). The data of them was completely improvised by me.
Starting yesterday I spent ~12h to figure out how to use our Zulip chat data in those regression models. I made countless efforts but couldn`t have any results. Then I didn`t want to accept my failure and decided to improvise its data. Used ChatGPT for codes of those 3 models and made them. if wonder was this way easy? no. it was a bit easier to deal with errors just because I was in a world of codes like Alice in Wonderland for a half-day :) @**Jaan Altosaar** I very much hope that this will be considered acceptable work :) 
Here is the Github access link: https://gulnaray-verbose-journey-r994p5xvvg7c59vv.github.dev/ My fav. one is the pic. with a star on it. No specific reason, I just liked the way it looks :)

zerver_message.subject: main
zerver_message.content:
haven't read every word of this article yet, but it also more or less tries to answer the same question we've been asking in class: "what happens when i click the 'send' button" https://www.newyorker.com/science/annals-of-artificial-intelligence/what-kind-of-mind-does-chatgpt-have  

with this paragraph giving a bit of a summary:

"If we really want to understand this technology, however, we also need to know something about how it’s implemented on real computers. When you submit a request to ChatGPT, the text you type into the OpenAI Web site is delivered to a control program running somewhere in a cloud-computing center. At this point, your text is packaged into a bunch of numbers, in a way that makes it easier for computers to understand and handle. It’s now ready to be processed by ChatGPT’s core program, which is made up of many distinct layers, each defined by a massive artificial neural network.

Your input will be passed along these layers in order—as if in a digital version of the telephone game—with each layer using its neural network to identify relevant features in the text, and then annotating it with summaries of what it discovered for later layers to use. The technical details of how these networks operate are a bit of a red herring for our purposes; what’s important to grasp is that, as a request moves through each layer, it triggers a vast number of inscrutable mathematical calculations that, together, execute something more or less like a condensed, jumbled-up version of the general rule-based word-voting strategy that we just described. The final output, after your input makes it through all of these layers, is something that approximates a vote count for each possible next word. The control program uses these counts to semi-randomly select what comes next. After all of this work, we have generated only a single word of ChatGPT’s response; the control program will dutifully add it to your original request and run this now slightly elongated text through all the neural-network layers from scratch, to generate the second word. Then it does this again, and again, until it has a complete answer to return to your Web browser."

zerver_message.subject: main
zerver_message.content:
@**everyone** // a good friend maida hadzi (https://www.linkedin.com/in/maidah/ / https://www.concordia.ca/artsci/research/loyola-sustainability/people/maidahadziosmanovic.html) is doing her phd on climate and sent over some resources for data. i know some data thinking learners here are interested in climate data (@**Indrek Romet** and others!) so i hope you find these useful. 

```
| Content/data                                       | Access                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  | Database/resource                                                            |
|----------------------------------------------------|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Climate laws/regulations/litigations/carbon prices | Free                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    | [climate-laws.org](https://climate-laws.org)                                |
| Emissions factors (geographically and temporally specific) | Some factors are free up to a limit. Contact the company (Ecometrica) for a license to access full database.                                                                                                                                                                         | [emissionfactors.com](https://www.emissionfactors.com)                      |
| Corporate emission footprints                      | Create account to access individual company responses (that include footprints). Buy license to access full global dataset of company responses.                                                                                                                                       | [cdp.net/en/data](https://www.cdp.net/en/data)                              |
| Corporate emission footprints                      | This was the best resource I had for corporate data, but you need a Terminal (very expensive) and an account. I was able to access one through my university for free. So, I would suggest asking around to see if anyone you know has access to one!                                   | Bloomberg Terminal                                                          |
| Global carbon emissions and carbon budgets         | Free (published every year in Earth System Science Data). To download data, go to 'Data Availability' section for the xlsx links.                                                                                                                                                     | [essd.copernicus.org/articles/14/4811/2022/](https://essd.copernicus.org/articles/14/4811/2022/)  |
| Various life-cycle data                            | Varied (see list)                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      | [ghgprotocol.org/life-cycle-databases](https://ghgprotocol.org/life-cycle-databases)                |
```

or as bullet points: 

 * Climate laws/regulations/litigations/carbon prices
** Free https://climate-laws.org

* Emissions factors (geographically and temporally specific) 
** Some factors are free up to a limit. Contact the company (Ecometrica) for a license to access full database. https://www.emissionfactors.com

* Corporate emission footprints
**Create account to access individual company responses (that include footprints). Buy license to access full global dataset of company responses.  https://www.cdp.net/en/data  

* Corporate emission footprints  
**This was the best resource I had for corporate data, but you need a Terminal (very expensive) and an account. I was able to access one through my university for free. So, I would suggest asking around to see if anyone you know has access to one! Bloomberg Terminal

* Global carbon emissions and carbon budgets 
**Free (published every year in Earth System Science Data). To download data, go to 'Data Availability' section for the xlsx links.
https://essd.copernicus.org/articles/14/4811/2022/

* Various life-cycle data
**Varied (see list) https://ghgprotocol.org/life-cycle-databases

please send over any more you may have like this! still working on united nations comtrade / supply chain data for y'all for final project potential.

zerver_message.content:
hello everyone. this might be a little too late but i would like to introduce myself. 
I'm Shailaja Mahara. I am a 1st year masters student of software engineering. My expectations from the course were to understand the implementations of the new AI language models, not necessarily just chatGPT and perhaps even discuss some nuances of having open access to a powerful AI tool  and how it might force us to reimagine "learning" and "knowledge".

zerver_message.subject: main
zerver_message.content:
@**everyone** i just sent all 160 learners on the data thinking list invites to anthropic.com's claude (we have been learning about their deal synopsis from pitchbook.com in several lectures).  

check it out! sign in with the same email you use here at https://console.anthropic.com/claude

context:

sam bankman-fried led the $580 million united states dollar series B funding of this private company.

therefore using this product may imply using stolen valor / stolen or fraudulent money to pay for the electricity cost of running `claude`. 

 (SBF is likely headed to jail this year after his house arrest right now) 

while we can't answer these questions, and there are conflict of interest / fiduciary responsibility clauses for stakeholders at anthropic, whether investors or employees who may worry about the usage of money whose fraudulence will be determined in court -- we can be mindful of it. 

claude is amazing and has worked significantly better than openai's GPT for certain categories of tasks, especially in software engineering relevant to data thinking. 

that is why i negotiated for us data thinking learners to get access to it in advance of the final project. 

the more tools the merrier, the more choices -- perhaps the more agency?

zerver_message.subject: Dreamstudio creations
zerver_message.content:
I knew that AI tools are pretty good at generating images, therefore I wanted to try out generation of charts and maps. 

First, I tried generating charts of covid cases in China, and while the results roughly look like a chart, they are not readable or meaningful. Also, it generates corporate-looking logos in the corners, so seems like that was the source for training initially. 
[image.png](/user_uploads/47304/SYeK_bIElTH5HXvaNB7qO78F/image.png)
[image.png](/user_uploads/47304/PG5R2VMRrtJQANsfLpqktFZ3/image.png)
I was wondering if it was a topic issue, therefore I also tried generating charts of stock prices, with limited success:
[image.png](/user_uploads/47304/BzGzFnCdL_iGgDwwg8oDFQGF/image.png)

After this, I completely pivoted and attempted to generate maps. The first thing that came to mind was the war in Ukraine, and I tried to map out the military movements. However, it did not understand that I wanted a map, and kept on generating artistic representations of the conflict. 
[image.png](/user_uploads/47304/az5eScfrHmscD3KyHn504BsK/image.png)
[image.png](/user_uploads/47304/KkmXxS937rqw2vn-a_L6KAby/image.png)
I was wondering if possibly the war was not part of the training data, so I tried something more general - a map of Lithuania:
[image.png](/user_uploads/47304/-ffJ9CXcxGLCVk8IRJhSWxB_/image.png)
There was no success again so I tried being more specific. The best results came when I specified which roads I wanted to see, but it's still hardly a usable map and more of an art piece you can put on the wall.
[image.png](/user_uploads/47304/ISxcePudW-aOlNethxATNmjA/image.png)
[image.png](/user_uploads/47304/8B03PcJIEt0-S-5GduDQvbBy/image.png)

In conclusion, Dreamstudio is great at making art, but not at creating images with discrete meaning.

zerver_message.subject: Polycam scans
zerver_message.content:
I tried out Polycam by scanning my watch. I was relatively surprised with the results, even though my phone does not have a depth sensor it could tell the shape pretty well (and my camera work wasn't optimal): https://poly.cam/capture/19e0374c-9e4a-4f56-bf61-116fcb0ab2d9

Afterwards, I was really interested in how it works on mostly transparent objects, so I tried an empty glass. It didn't work out as well: https://poly.cam/capture/b36c48ea-2380-4138-a324-2403385b4cae

zerver_message.subject: plotting
zerver_message.content:
I have read the data using duck db, but I can't say I found a reasonable advantage for using it, as in the end we still read the data to and from dataframes (for Altair visualisation). Feels a bit like going around in circles, but in general duckdb is a useful tool to know.

For the visualisation itself, I generated text embeddings from the content of the messages (using the DistilBERT language model), and after extracting the main features using PCA tried to see if there was a clear similarity in messages sent on the same day of the week. Turns out, there's no similarity (or at least DistilBERT doesn't see them as similar). 
[image.png](/user_uploads/47304/0HnZjfvaNku-ZUHvtBLtIW-M/image.png)

```

Hey, I think you can have a look at the definitions we had during one of the classes [here](https://www.figma.com/file/HZmhf20kKr8lC9dPJz56Ri/230403-teaching-philosoph-course-review-defining-data-and-thinking-and-self-gaslighting?type=whiteboard&node-id=0-1&t=qvPkXnwygZfXenfg-0 ) . Then, you can open the [wikipage](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_thinking) and think about what you can add to this page: maybe something is missing, or there is some unreliable stuff, or there is an aspect of our definition that is not even mentioned in the wiki page. When you get an idea you just click the 'edit' button,  I used the Visual editor, but you can use the source editor if you want to try MediaWiki markup. To make an edit, you have to leave a comment about what exactly you changed. Admins and advanced users later may decline a change but it will be still recorded in the page history.

zerver_message.subject: Final Project
zerver_message.content:
So I've decided to put my project's topic here:)
As I mentioned in the first homework, I am passionate about the thought that everything around us is information in different types. However, not all the information is always the truth and it may be dangerous. Since I am Ukrainian, I understand really well that fake information in some situations (e.g. during the war) may cost a lot of lives so it is important to have the mechanisms to separate truth from lie.
My research question will be "How can domain knowledge-driven rules help mitigate the spread of misinformation on social media platforms?". I am planning to use the Fake News Challenge dataset (https://www.fakenewschallenge.org/) for it.
zerver_message.rendered_content:

My research question will be "How can domain knowledge-driven rules help mitigate the spread of misinformation on social media platforms?". I am planning to use the Fake News Challenge dataset (https://www.fakenewschallenge.org/) for it.

zerver_message.subject: main
zerver_message.content:
@**everyone** -- reposting here -- please come to the lecture tomorrow! it is the final one and took a lot of logistics across africa, north america, asia to coordinate (our guest lecturer and i have have had to coordinate this while doing round-the-world travel!). 

Dear data thinkers,

Please join the •••final lecture••• for this pilot of data thinking -- we couldn't have created this course without you, and as a thank you have arranged this special guest lecture.

OUR TEACHER:

None other than Professor Tegan Maharaj from the University of Toronto!

WHEN:

16:16 Eastern European Time || 09:16 Eastern Standard Time [the usual]

WHERE:

Link in the calendar event: https://calendar.datathinking.org/harms-from-increasingly-agentic-algorithmic-systems ~-~ please add this to your calendar now! ~-~

WHAT:

Tegan will illuminate us on the nuances of risk perception and measurement, contrasting the differences between physics-based simulation and agent-based models.

She'll put these concepts into a real-life context by teaching us:

    how she used agent-based models were for proactive contact tracing in her work: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/36913342/
    how you can develop a small agent-based model related to an issue of your interest, whether it's carbon emissions, AI's impact on job markets, or car crash rates, using a tutorial available here: https://mesa.readthedocs.io/en/stable/tutorials/intro_tutorial.html
    "Harms from Increasingly Agentic Systems" (Tegan's recent work! https://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10329).  
    [Potentially!] This intriguing paper about metadata archaeology: https://metadata-archaeology.github.io/


Our guest lecture will encourage us to question the traditional pipeline and contemplate how non-tabular "data sources," like agent-based models, can be a potent tool in our data thinking arsenal.

This is a unique opportunity to broaden your horizons and delve into these concepts with Tegan, a world-class researcher who...

    has been featured in the Economist (for her AI in climate work: https://impact.economist.com/perspectives/sustainability/green-intelligence-ai-could-boost-efforts-fight-climate-change)
    started her academic bildungsroman in biology with a focus on health and neuropsychology before transitioning to ecology
    and who, while analyzing results for her honors research in bioremediation, was introduced to programming for the first time and quickly developed a passion for machine learning.

Not to be missed =-)

Yours in scouting,
J

P.S. The final projects are looking AMAZING (!!!), and I'm here to help if you're stuck. Reach out on Zulip or here!

P.P.S. Please find attached the slides from the previous guest lecture on deep reinforcement learning for agent-based modeling of the entire economy, a nice counterpart to what Tegan is teaching us about.

zerver_message.subject: plotting
zerver_message.content:
I was playing around with the zulipchat data using duckdb. I created these plots. Firstly, the number of most frequent user senders (I used sender IDs, and Others is a joint category for those who only sent one message) 
[image.png](/user_uploads/47304/T8JKcPCK89sR5vhGRG0PPIeM/image.png)
 Secondly,  I made a simple plot sorting number of messages over time. 
[image.png](/user_uploads/47304/mMvO3QSuy0BKJPoTpqmPOCPK/image.png)
Thirdly, I looked at the number of messages sent on each day of the week (no surprises that Monday and Thursday win - two days when we had classes) 
[image.png](/user_uploads/47304/tL5QbVrh5_ByhK68pwfwHqJs/image.png)
We also haven't started to send more messages with attachments during the time (this was contrary to my intuition) 
[image.png](/user_uploads/47304/gFX9x-WTD4F6hxhHNiUjTJt3/image.png)
And finally, we rarely edit our messages 
[image.png](/user_uploads/47304/_AtyKmkhNBn5k14I3te4IeAp/image.png)

That's all from me.

zerver_message.subject: Final Project
zerver_message.content:
Hi, I wrote my blogpost; you can find it [here](https://github.com/nshut/datathinking_blogpost_TrumpTweetsFigLeaves/blob/main/TrumpTweetsFigLeavesPost.md)

In this project, I aimed to explore the concept of "fig leaves" - utterances or actions that provide cover for statements or behaviors that would otherwise be seen as racist - in the context of Donald Trump's tweets (Notable example of a fig leave is "I am not a racist, but *very racist claim*"). I created a search engine capable of finding tweets relevant to a given topic, thereby enabling the analysis and understanding of the use of fig leaves in Trump's discourse on Twitter. The project was driven by the challenge of applying machine learning and natural language processing techniques to real-world, complex dataset, and a desire to shed light on the subtle ways in which language can be used to mask or deflect from problematic statements or actions. However, I failed to create a pull request, but I made my own open repository with all files and shared the link.

zerver_message.subject: experience reports
zerver_message.content:
Here's my experience report...it's going to be more like a RANT because that's kinda what I need in this moment. I'm feeling many parts angry, antsy, anxious, and stressed right now. I just read that imposter syndrome article in the new yorker and it pushed many chords in me. I personally could've done without the ending of the article where the author universalizes "imposter phenomenom" to life experience in a very white-liberal move. But overall, great read- especially its meditation on how for people of color, the term "imposter syndrome" pathologizes individual experience and obscures the systemic racism that often manifests feelings of fraudulence and self-doubt.

What really tightened a knot in my chest was the anecdote about Adaira Landry, a first-gen African American woman, whose feelings of self-doubt were *dismissed* as imposter syndrome. Looking back, Landry sees that what she needed was recognition that her feelings were real, and coerced into existence by systemic racism that shaped her existence on the med school campus.

This is the recognition that Landry provides her students now, and she can see the relief from her students when hearing these words. THIS is the dynamic that has me a bit stressed, because it brings me back to my time working for the McGraw center at Princeton, a tutoring and learning resource for students. I was a learning consultant in 2021-2022, and a similar method I would use would be to tell students that Princeton's academic structure was built against them. **And I'd get so so much push back from my peers during trainings when I would introduce this method.** Because of the support I didn't get in my training and from the McGraw center, I even felt scared at times to tell Black/POC students that their "imposter" feelings and their struggles in the classroom weren't on them but rather because of the hegemony of the classroom and academic structure. It felt like a truth only to be spoken behind close doors, which makes sense... because McGraw is Princeton's creation, partly functioning to train students to tutor and help each other so the University doesn't have to reduce course loads, or lengthen academic terms, or alleviate academic/graduation requirements.

I even felt so compelled as to write a note to my former McGraw boss on these thoughts and share/summarize the article for them. I feel so freaking jittery and anxious right now because this is the feeling I get when I stand-up for myself or speak up blejhajsdbfjksadbfjksdafdjsk. refleciton complete.

tl;dr liked the imposter article. stressed because it implicates how imposter syndrome is talked abt at Princeton but also how it's perpetuated by student resource centers like McGraw. stressed also because I complained to my former McGRaw boss (Nic Voge) abt it.
zerver_message.rendered_content:
Here's my experience report...it's going to be more like a RANT because that's kinda what I need in this moment. I'm feeling many parts angry, antsy, anxious, and stressed right now. I just read that imposter syndrome article in the new yorker and it pushed many chords in me. I personally could've done without the ending of the article where the author universalizes "imposter phenomenom" to life experience in a very white-liberal move. But overall, great read- especially its meditation on how for people of color, the term "imposter syndrome" pathologizes individual experience and obscures the systemic racism that often manifests feelings of fraudulence and self-doubt.

What really tightened a knot in my chest was the anecdote about Adaira Landry, a first-gen African American woman, whose feelings of self-doubt were dismissed as imposter syndrome. Looking back, Landry sees that what she needed was recognition that her feelings were real, and coerced into existence by systemic racism that shaped her existence on the med school campus.

This is the recognition that Landry provides her students now, and she can see the relief from her students when hearing these words. THIS is the dynamic that has me a bit stressed, because it brings me back to my time working for the McGraw center at Princeton, a tutoring and learning resource for students. I was a learning consultant in 2021-2022, and a similar method I would use would be to tell students that Princeton's academic structure was built against them. And I'd get so so much push back from my peers during trainings when I would introduce this method. Because of the support I didn't get in my training and from the McGraw center, I even felt scared at times to tell Black/POC students that their "imposter" feelings and their struggles in the classroom weren't on them but rather because of the hegemony of the classroom and academic structure. It felt like a truth only to be spoken behind close doors, which makes sense... because McGraw is Princeton's creation, partly functioning to train students to tutor and help each other so the University doesn't have to reduce course loads, or lengthen academic terms, or alleviate academic/graduation requirements.

I even felt so compelled as to write a note to my former McGraw boss on these thoughts and share/summarize the article for them. I feel so freaking jittery and anxious right now because this is the feeling I get when I stand-up for myself or speak up blejhajsdbfjksadbfjksdafdjsk. refleciton complete.

tl;dr liked the imposter article. stressed because it implicates how imposter syndrome is talked abt at Princeton but also how it's perpetuated by student resource centers like McGraw. stressed also because I complained to my former McGRaw boss (Nic Voge) abt it.

zerver_message.subject: experience reports
zerver_message.content:
Wow I really appreciate your experience @**Daniel Wey** 🙏. I’m proud of you for (1) going above and beyond your role at McGraw to help Black/POC students understand the broader hegemony of academia and classrooms. And (2) being able to eloquently connect the dots between this slew of difficult personal experiences getting shut down while trying to help… 

Student resource centers are in an interesting bind. If they implicate themselves (and acquiesce to your implication of the hegemony and structure having adverse consequences for some students vs others), then legal liability can be created. See for example the many cases of students allegedly feeling forced to withdraw after mental health crises were learned about by the school: https://www.chronicle.com/article/sent-away

In this case, I see a similarity to “AI safety” discussions held at big tech companies being an attractive way to deflect discussion of greater harms occurring immediately rather than in the far-off future. Perhaps “impostor syndrome” and its attendant word salad can serve a similar purpose for student resource centers who choose to avoid discussion of power structures and hegemony as you rightfully suggest they do. Well done.⚡️

zerver_message.subject: experience reports
zerver_message.content:
Hello everyone, here’s my experience report:
Have you ever been given a task and in your head you are extremely confident you can perform said task furthermore perform it quickly. Then all of a sudden that task turns out to be harder than expected. You keep performing the instructions and keep getting the same answer of an error. Because of your confidence you don’t think “hey maybe the instructions are wrong” and due to this you keep making the same mistake. 
Jaan’s lecture was amazing and the best part for me was when he went through the instructions and basically said that they were bad. Going on then to show us to think outside the box. This evidently is what helped me the most through the installation process. The terminal was stating that I did not have Pip and conda downloaded. And because of that I could not download all the other extensions and data. I kept repeating the instructions believing something was wrong with my computer until I thought maybe the instructions itself were wrong. That’s when I went directly and downloaded an andaconda Mac OS intel installer. Performed the tasks then CREATED a path for conda. Then I downloaded python 3.11 and Pip on my Mac. These steps were not on the list. After that everything went smoothly. I’m on the data visualization part and I believe that I will still run into problems however I also believe thinking outside the box will help me again.

zerver_message.subject: experience reports
zerver_message.content: Hi all! My experience report: as I was working through these homework tasks, I was struck by the fact that the various ideas brought up in the readings, exercises, and coding problems all come from various disciplines - from etymology to psychology to programmatic computer science. I found myself aiming to connect the dots between these moving parts as I progressed through the homework. I'm interested to continue developing this approach to data thinking - far more unique and transdisciplinary than any previous CS courses I have taken, which tend to privilege mathematical/scientific knowledge above other forms!

zerver_message.subject: experience reports
zerver_message.content: Hello everyone, my experience report: I have had trouble setting up virtual environments in the past, so I was worried about running into errors setting up this environment. I ran into issues with my virtual environment having all of the installed packages, but the Jupyter notebook still returning errors that different modules could not be found. I eventually realized that because I have multiple versions of Python on my laptop, the packages I installed for my virtual environment needed to be reinstalled on a different path for a different Python interpreter. This resolved most of my issues, and it was satisfying to better understand how the virtual environment works. I still have one module not found error, but I’ll attend office hours to help resolve that problem, and I’m looking forward to getting into the data justice work once our set up is complete. I also thought the other tasks of putting my phone on do not disturb was really helpful for my focus, but tracking every minute of my day on Google calendar was less effective because I would feel bad if I got off-schedule and felt like I didn't have as much freedom in my day.

I also thought the other tasks of putting my phone on do not disturb was really helpful for my focus, but tracking every minute of my day on Google calendar was less effective because I would feel bad if I got off-schedule and felt like I didn't have as much freedom in my day.

zerver_message.subject: plotting
zerver_message.content:
Hey! I finally did the analysis of the zulip chat data: https://github.com/onefact/datathinking.org/issues/132#issuecomment-1587425686

My findings include that it is very easy to predict the zulip subject just from message embeddings (96 dimensional using spacy). Linear regression from those embeddings to message length in words was ok but less successful. I think the logistic regression overfitted though. The plot I chose to share shows the distribution of message length in the embedding space (dimensionality reduced using PCA). Most of the outliers are from the "linkedin profile" subject, which is to be excpected because messages there follow vastly different statistics.

[lengths.png](/user_uploads/47304/Vr1uBhZFjL1uoBk-0017lhb8/lengths.png)

zerver_message.subject: Lab Meeting Reflections
zerver_message.content: In the Examining Power chapter of Data Feminism, Catherine D’Ignazio and Lauren F. Klein address the “diversity solution” to data and tech injustice. Diversifying the tech force would combat what D’Ignazio and Klein call the “privilege hazard,” which describes how those who occupy the most privileged positions are not equipped to recognize oppression–and therefore also unable to actively resist it. We believe that more minoritized voices in higher positions would trickle down to diversify datasets and make algorithms more just. However, this is not the comprehensive solution some may think it is. As we learn in the example about the facial database deal with the Zimbabwe government and CloudWalk, diversity in data [and the workforce] must be dealt with cautiously.

zerver_message.subject: Lab Meeting Reflections
zerver_message.content: Chapter 4 “What Gets Counted Counts” introduces the idea of flawed classification systems. These flaws we find in algorithms stem from the human case. The different biases and patterns which exist in the data are transferred into the algorithm, and AI loses its perceived objectivity. In his book *The Alignment Problem* Brian Christian recounts inherent gender bias in some of the earlier AI models. Prompts like "doctor + woman" would reveal nurse. AI can perpetuate the social constructs present in the data that it is trained on and this seems to be a problem with people rather than the algorithms.
