zerver_message.subject: Lab Meeting Reflections
zerver_message.content: I read an initiative put forth by Amazon, Google and Microsoft to educate children in Boston on AI.  While it was interesting that they were investing in this as it is believed AI will create a new demand for jobs I could not help but think about the vested interest they had.  Though they were teaching them how to use A.I to program Alexa, the article also said that the companies failed to mention their policy on its use.  They also had incentive to reinforce their way of using AI which could be harmful not only to these students but the greater public.  Later in the article it talked about the ethics of artificial intelligence usage and fairness and equality.  This brought me back to chapter 2 of the assigned reading. In this the authors said words such as fairness, equality, and ethics do not go far enough and secure power by legitimizing these structures.  However we instead need to be seeking justice, equity and co-liberation by challenging powerful structures such as these companies. I think children should be taught how to use AI but we need to question who is deciding the curriculum and who has a vested interest in shaping what is taught.

zerver_message.subject: Lab Meeting Reflections
zerver_message.content: Many existing datasets are labeled as biased because their data does not accurately represent certain populations. One example of this is the ImageNet dataset, and researchers have tried to “unbias” this dataset by either removing or augmenting some images, or making datasets available that are balanced by age, gender expression, or skin color. In Chapter 2 of Data Feminism, D’Ignazio and Klein discuss how removing bias or promoting fairness is insufficient, and instead we should challenge power through justice, co-liberation, and historical/cultural understanding. Not only does this require us to be careful with existing datasets, but they also emphasize the importance of missing datasets, and how this reflects which groups are worth representing in data.
zerver_message.rendered_content: Many existing datasets are labeled as biased because their data does not accurately represent certain populations. One example of this is the ImageNet dataset, and researchers have tried to “unbias” this dataset by either removing or augmenting some images, or making datasets available that are balanced by age, gender expression, or skin color. In Chapter 2 of Data Feminism, D’Ignazio and Klein discuss how removing bias or promoting fairness is insufficient, and instead we should challenge power through justice, co-liberation, and historical/cultural understanding. Not only does this require us to be careful with existing datasets, but they also emphasize the importance of missing datasets, and how this reflects which groups are worth representing in data.

zerver_message.subject: Lab Meeting Reflections
zerver_message.content: In chapter 3 of Data Feminism, D’Ignazio and Klein discuss false perceptions of data visualizations’ objectivity. They attribute the widespread belief that these visualizations are neutral and objective to common quantification practices’ resistance of emotion. Challenging this belief, Klein and D’Ignazio highlight data visualization’s tendency to merely reflect the perspective of privileged social groups and the need for data visualizations that elevate emotion rather than resist it. Their discussion of the devaluation of emotion-driven forms of knowledge and knowledge sharing relates to current conversations surrounding AI as a tool for “objective” decision-making within various different industries. Proponents of AI as a decision-making tool often cite its neutrality as a benefit. However, as Klein and D’Ignazio point out, this perspective not only overlooks the bias often embedded in algorithms, but also ignores emotion’s ability to serve as a basis for equitable decision-making.

zerver_message.subject: Lab Meeting Reflections
zerver_message.content: The chapter four delves into the topic of classification systems and their susceptibility to human influence, particularly through implicit biases known as "algorithmic stereotypes." These biases arise due to the absence of certain datasets and the underrepresentation of minority groups in decision-making roles within datasets. This lack of recognition of minority perspectives results in an inadequate representation of the various biases and oppressions prevalent in today's world, which are crucial to be incorporated into the data and subsequently transferred to the algorithm for unbiased outcomes. However, this approach can also have adverse consequences, as individuals from minority backgrounds in positions of power may unintentionally introduce their own biases and perpetuate privilege, leading to a dearth of representation and meaningful contributions in both the datasets and algorithms.

zerver_message.subject: Lab Meeting Reflections
zerver_message.content: Chapter 4 of Data Feminism talks about how categorizing people in certain ways such as by binary genders leads to unfairness and inaccuracies in data. Since AI works mainly by machine learning which includes a lot of categorization, people who do not fit easily into these constructed categories can be harmed by this. These people may be not included in data since they may not want to fit themselves into categories where they don't feel comfortable. Even if they do choose one of these options though, the data is still inaccurate because it is categorizing people incorrectly. This can lead to AI predictions being less accurate for these people than people who more strongly identify with the categories in which they are placed.

zerver_message.subject: Lab Meeting Reflections
zerver_message.content: I think Data Feminism does a great job of explaining how a moratorium on AI in fields like policing is necessary, but not because these institutions are misusing the algorithms in the conventional sense. While the book does go into depth about the harms of missing data, a key insight in chapter 2 is that even if all the data are available and the algorithm runs as it should, because criminal justice in the US is a systematically racist institution to begin with, AI will only help it become a more efficent engine of systemic racism rather than somehow alleviating a structural issue. There is nuance in that the question of who will actually recedivate while out on bail is in practice a very different question than who was caught recedivating in the past because racial bias in policing leads to skewed data and skewed predictions. The moratorium is then needed because regardless of variable selection, drawing from a biased data set that is biased due to deeper, structural racism will only produce the same result again but with the shiny new promise of advancing technology.

zerver_message.subject: Lab Meeting Reflections
zerver_message.content:
As a data scientist, I find it fascinating to witness the intersection of data science and social equity. The fact that data science and artificial intelligence fields are predominantly dominated by elite white men raises significant concerns about the potential biases and privileges that can be inadvertently embedded in the systems and algorithms they create. It becomes increasingly vital to acknowledge the collective privilege hazard that exists and recognize the limitations of this homogeneous perspective.
Kate Crawford's perspective on the threat posed by artificial intelligence systems is thought-provoking. Rather than simply focusing on the possibility of machines surpassing human intelligence, she highlights the risks of perpetuating sexism, racism, and other forms of discrimination by encoding biased assumptions and data into the digital fabric of our societies. This raises important ethical questions about the responsibility of data scientists to address and rectify such biases within their work.
I thought it was crucial to differentiate between the actual scientific principles underlying data science and the individuals involved in the practice. While data science itself is a powerful tool for uncovering insights and drawing inferences, it is the people driving its application who must be held accountable for the ethical implications of their work. By utilizing data science to shed light on issues like the wage and promotion gap based on gender like Darden did, we can expose and challenge the existing inequalities that persist in society.

zerver_message.subject: Lab Meeting Reflections
zerver_message.content: In Chapter 2 of Data Feminism something that stuck out to me was the idea of equity. D’Ignazio and Klein explain Costanza-Chock’s idea that we should be designing algorithms that are “just” instead of “color-blind.” This is something that seems very difficult to achieve on its own due to the fact that algorithms can be influenced by the bias of their creators and that a good amount are trained using past history (which doesn’t share this goal of equity). Yet the authors maintain the view that algorithms acting in this manner is something that is not impossible to achieve. There is a thin line between equality and equity so I’m wondering what this line is for algorithms? D’Ignazio and Klein attempted to distinguish between the two concepts in terms of algorithms, but it was a bit unclear for me. Moreover, besides combatting structural oppression, what steps can be taken to make algorithms achieve equity?

zerver_message.subject: Lab Meeting Reflections
zerver_message.content: At the beginning of the text, Data Feminism, the authors refers to the expansion of what is normally defined as "data" and "data science". They write that although when the majority think about data they think of just numbers, but in fact data can also consist of  words, stories or any information that is collectable. This expansive envisoning of data science combats the dominant exclusionary, elite terminology that is aimed to keep certain type of people in the know while at the same time excluding others under the basis of credentials, profession, education level etc to maintain power.  The Power Chapter, through the example of Serena Williams pregnancy post, showcase how what type of data collected is a marker of what/who is valued within our society. The fact that there is no national system for tracking childbirth complications,  along with the limited data on materal morality and along with the racial disparities that affect Black women, it makes it harder for Black women and other groups to speak out and be heard on the oppression they face.

zerver_message.subject: Lab Meeting Reflections
zerver_message.content: What data feminism reminded me is the importance of questioning the underlying values and hierarchies within our technological systems – critically examining classifications based on gender, biases favoring reason over emotion, or the separation of nature and culture. Recently, I came across an article from "Wired" highlighting how healthcare algorithms, designed to address disparities, might inadvertently exacerbate the very issues they aim to solve, further underscoring the need to critically assess the impact of algorithms and classification systems. In retrospect, many algorithms striving for "algorithmic fairness" are developed without considering policy and societal contexts, resulting in a lack of consensus on the definition of fairness itself.

zerver_message.subject: experience reports
zerver_message.content:
I actually already use google calendar to schedule my day almost minute to minute because it reduces my anxiety about making sure I have enough time to get everything done while also showing me where more flexibility is in my schedule. This assignment really made me think about why I do it, since I almost never do everything exactly as planned. Honestly more times than not I just use it as a general guide of how my day should be structured. I realized that I like being able to move things around when my plans change while knowing I still will have time to get everything done. Additionally, I change my calendar to match what I actually did that day which is super helpful for looking back to see what events I had on what days. It makes me happy to look at both the things that I actually did and my plans for the future.

chatgbt edit: I already use Google Calendar to schedule my day, often down to the minute, which helps alleviate my anxiety about managing my time effectively. zerver_message.subject: experience reports
zerver_message.content:
Here is my experience report: I found all of the required readings to be really compelling but I really was interested in the you're probably using the wrong dictionary article.  Often I know words but then I think what is the exact definition and I google it.  It can be the most mundane word but I like to do it.  This article challenged me because it challenged the precise nature of the dictionary we use today.  As they put it they "boil it down to her essence".  What really stuck out was that they said to use anything but the dictionary that was more descriptive was "to keep yourself forever at the arms length from the actual language."  It made me think about how we use science and reason to try to explain our world and how as we advance as a society we feel more need to control as if that will bring us closer to understand everything.  I think this may be why we have forgone these more in depth and almost uncertain definitions in the 1913 Webster's dictionary and replaced it with our succinct definitions we have today.  I think it is cool there exists this dictionary and as the article said it reminds us that words existed before the definition which I think is the best way we should think of words.

Coding: I always struggle to start the coding section.  I always feel like I am inherently going to be bad at it and also I think anytime you are used to excelling it is difficult to start learning something new.  It requires you to be a novice and out in time.  When you don't immediately see results you can feel discouraged and not want to continue and avoid it.  I eventually tried to build the environment and was confused by the article and then the second sequence in Visual Code Studio.  I was frustrated with the environment and not knowing how to do it.  But then I remembered I could use ChatGPT.  In asking ChatGPT I was able to get further into the environment building. But then I also got stuck at writing the line into file.  When I asked ChatGPT it said that I had to use Visual Code but I was not sure if that was right so then I got frustrated again.  

It is cool however that there exists this thing called Terminal that has always existed on my computer and I never knew about it or that I could use it.  It is crazy how we can think we know how to use our computer when really we only use a portion of it as we know how to do.

@*data thinking bootcamp* action item before 6pm if you have a few minutes:

* watch the videos here: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLU_yLxZZV6EAAD9LqsWq-P2tG1Oxr-7sf

* read the description of a video or the playlist

* think about which maps you find yourself on the edges of, and ask: who gets to decide which data and which algorithms are worth using to control the map? what goals do the map-makers and delivery mechanisms embody? in what ways may thay restrict your movements within the map and outside of it? what data is needed to achieve these goals, whether explicit or implicit?

zerver_message.subject: experience reports
zerver_message.content:
Here’s my experience attempting to visualize the call data after building the environment and opening the notebook in Visual Studio Code: 
I ran into a lot of roadblocks throughout the process, as downloading the data, reading the CSV file, and importing the necessary packages all resulted in confusing errors.  I asked ChatGPT for help with all these steps. However, a lot of the solutions it offered were inapplicable, so this process was more frustrating than I anticipated. I eventually turned to Google for help instead. For certain portions, this proved to be more helpful. For others, I found that solutions on sites like StackOverflow either didn’t relate closely enough to my issue or were confusing to implement. 
I was relieved to eventually find solutions to all my early issues. I made it to the  “Visualizing the data” portion of the notebook and thought things would go relatively smoothly here, but I immediately ran into more problems. Importing Vegafusion resulted in a ModuleNotFoundError that I couldn’t figure out how to solve, regardless of what I searched online or asked ChatGPT. This reflects one of my major struggles with working in Visual Studio Code. Ensuring necessary packages are downloaded into the right place feels pretty tedious and confusing. There were a lot of times where I would feel confident I was downloading something into the correct location only to get a ModuleNotFoundError when I tried to import it later on.

zerver_message.subject: Final Project
zerver_message.content:
Here is a description of my final project:

:suburb: **LIFEWISE** (Life Index for Well-being and Expense Sustainability) project utilizes regression analysis to identify optimal places to live, considering the balance between well-being and expenses. It offers actionable insights for individuals seeking high-quality living within their budget, while providing decision-making support for policymakers, urban planners, and real estate developers. The project aims to empower individuals and communities to make informed choices that enhance their overall quality of life and long-term sustainability.

The topic of LIFEWISE holds deep personal significance to me, as it is rooted in my own journey of seeking a new home in Europe. Having been forced to move because of war, I found myself faced with the daunting task of deciding where to rebuild my life. With limited knowledge about European countries and their living conditions, I yearned for a data-driven approach to guide my decision-making process. It was this pivotal moment that sparked my interest in exploring the balance between quality of life and cost of living. Through the LIFEWISE project, I aim to empower individuals like myself, who seek a fresh start in unfamiliar territories, by providing actionable insights that enable informed choices.

I went to office hours and I think this was super helpful. I ave always been afraid of using Visual Studio code. I had a class last semester where I chose to code on the terminal in the emacs editor rather than download VS code and set it up. That being said, I am happy I managed, through Jaan's amazing help, to navigate the instructions and see the visualizations.

zerver_message.subject: main
zerver_message.content:
@*data thinking bootcamp*  // just added the office hours link for today -- https://panopto.ut.ee/Panopto/Pages/Sessions/List.aspx?folderID=bab0e967-b371-40f1-8583-b01901856db5 

key takeaway: the very first part of the homework says something like grab a piece of paper (or e-ink tablet, maybe not an ipad because internet distracts). it's easy to miss that part. but it also helps skipping steps or making sure to set a timer for 5 minutes the moment you notice something being stuck. 

super proud of everyone's hard work!!!! folks are starting to be able to visualize hundreds of thousands (at least) phone calls for new york city, one of the biggest cities in the world, all on their laptops. that's a LOT of work in a little over a week. make sure to chill this weekend and celebrate the wins, the earlier the better!!!!!! :raised_hands:

zerver_message.edit_history:
[{"user_id":623389,"timestamp":1687134272,"prev_content":"June 12: Data Feminism Chapter 4 reflection(sorry for the late reply): In Chapter 4, the authors introduced an idea that intrigued me. The process of data analysis and creation of data is inherently intertwined and influenced by political and social themes of society. When the authors explained the enumeration process, it displayed an argument to me that sometimes significant events can be minimized down to a number, which might misrepresent it and strip away importance from that event. On the other hand, turning an event into a number can also greaten its importance and overestimate it. However, individuals, too, can end up just being a statistic or number. By turning an individual into a number, various arbitrary matters become unquantifiable and are not counted. So what does get counted? Yet the authors also introduce the question of who decides what gets measured. Data Colonialism shows us that if data collection is not monitored and checked, does in power will abuse their power and control what gets counted. zerver_message.content: June 12: Data Feminism Chapter 4 reflection(sorry for the late reply): In Chapter 4, the authors introduced an idea that intrigued me. The process of data analysis and creation of data is inherently intertwined and influenced by political and social themes of society. When the authors explained the enumeration process, it displayed an argument to me that sometimes significant events can be minimized down to a number, which might misrepresent it and strip away importance from that event. On the other hand, turning an event into a number can also greaten its importance and overestimate it. However, individuals, too, can end up just being a statistic or number. By turning an individual into a number, various arbitrary matters become unquantifiable and are not counted. So what does get counted? Yet the authors also introduce the question of who decides what gets measured. After reading a condensed summarization of this chapter-(helped by ChatGPT),  I grasped the importance of data collection and made sure to constantly question what data is being collected and how it is being collected.

zerver_message.subject: experience reports
zerver_message.content: My experience report is that when trying to start up python and the conda environment in visual studio code felt like being a baby locked in a hot car. Time was passing, nothing was getting solved, and I had no idea what was going on. I felt better in bootcamp meetings finding out that others were also lost along the way, and eventually I figured things out. I found taking breaks helped, and sometimes it seemed like code I tried before that failed just needed to be run again. It was very cool to see things work out and know support is available, but also gratifying to solve even small issues. It is uncomfortable to work on things without any idea how long they will take. I know, for example, roughly how long it will take me to read data feminism because I read at a consistent speed. With the bootcamp tasks, things I thought would take 10 minutes took hours, and things I thought would take forever ended up not being so bad. I think getting comfortable with that unpredictability helps mitigate frustration. I have enjoyed playing with chatGPT and even being encouraged to do so.

zerver_message.subject: Lab Meeting Reflections
zerver_message.content: A key tenet of freedom schools is deconstructing notions of  the normalized teacher-student relationships. In the freedom schools in the 1960s, students weren’t only kids, but also parents and grandparents. The instructors took on roles in their relationships with the students that went beyond passing on information and a youth-centered pedagogy was used to design a progressive curriculum, instead of allowing adults to simply prescribe what they think the students ought to know. So, if we were to be teaching data feminism with these strategies, it would involve listening to students to understand what they know about everything related to data, feminism, and data feminism, and using that as a guide to build a curriculum. It would also adopt the youth-led model where students are put in the position to teach each other. A key principle of both freedom school pedagogy and data feminism is building collectivity and providing tools for the community to fight back. While teaching students about the tenets of data feminism, we would also have to (1) equip them with the tools so that they can continue to teach data feminism in future environments and (2) provide opportunities for the students to interact and build community with each other.

zerver_message.subject: Lab Meeting Reflections
zerver_message.content: Question for Prof. Jon Hale: How do you think about the difference between implementing freedom school strategies into our already existing educational institutions versus creating more independent freedom schools? To what extent is the former counterproductive?
zerver_message.rendered_content: Question for Prof. Jon Hale: How do you think about the difference between implementing freedom school strategies into our already existing educational institutions versus creating more independent freedom schools? To what extent is the former counterproductive?

zerver_message.subject: Lab Meeting Reflections
zerver_message.content: Reflection for June 19th: From my reading of the freedom school article, the way that freedom schools attracted and retained students may be an interesting way to teach data feminism. I think a lot of captivating starter questions could come from this topic, such as: how did the enrollment of students change over time (and why) or how did the recruitment strategies implemented by the freedom schools affect their retention rates. These questions could evolve into deeper research questions in which data can be used to explore. I think that context and challenging subjugated knowledge, as mentioned in chapter six of Data Feminism, would be very important to the research here because it would capture the depth of the raw data of retention rates and give the “why” or meaning to why the data is important. Without the why/meaning it’s difficult to draw any substantial conclusions from the raw data. In regard to this exploration, it is also possible to learn from these retention rates and create a curriculum/environment that is engaging for all students, young and older, to learn about data feminism. Question for Professor Jon Hale: What steps can be taken to implement freedom school education topics/strategies into today’s schools where minorities are the minority? What can the minorities at these schools do to ensure their voices are heard? What encouragement can we provide them?

zerver_message.subject: Lab Meeting Reflections
zerver_message.content:
By incorporating Data Feminism principles, we can learn how to challenge and reshape the dominant narratives and power structures prevalent in data science. The emphasis on inclusivity, ethics, and social justice can help students recognize the biases and injustices embedded within data and analytics. In a Data Feminism-focused Freedom School, students would analyze data through an intersectional lens, considering how gender, race, and other social categories intersect to shape the outcomes and interpretations of data. 

Question: In what ways can the concept of Freedom Schools inform current efforts to improve educational opportunities and outcomes for marginalized communities?

zerver_message.subject: Lab Meeting Reflections
zerver_message.content: A freedom school strategy that may be used to teach data feminism is disrupting existing dominant power structures and allow marginalized voices to be heard as described in Chapter 5 of "Data Feminism." Existing dominant power structures of education include the lack of questioning authority and the lack of engaging in social change. Freedom Schools disrupt these power structures by encouraging students to do the opposite—which, in the context of data feminism, students would be encouraged to question data that is deemed as "good" or socially-engaged. Not only that, but also to vocalize how to improve the data to become more socially-engaged, perhaps by incorporating and valuing more marginalized voices (if needed). My question to Prof. Hale is the following: What strategies from the history of Freedom Schools and their struggle for educational quality do you believe are most relevant to addressing the inequities in our education system (if possible, in relation to the intersection of data feminism)?

zerver_message.subject: Lab Meeting Reflections
zerver_message.content:
I think that the way freedom schools got out their message and recruited students and teachers would be beneficial to the teaching of data feminism. The marches and demonstrations spread awareness for the Civil Rights Movement which then spurred more people to join the movement. These people inspired others to join their mission in ways that were extremely effective. I think data feminism could use this by using new techniques of getting their message out into the world such as social media and by connecting people in different ways such as over zoom or other communication apps. In this way, the ideas that are central to data feminism will reach many people across the world and will hopefully lead to necessary changes in the field.

Question: How do you think Freedom Schools should be the same as they were originally and how should they be different in today's society?

zerver_message.subject: Lab Meeting Reflections
zerver_message.content:
Freedom Schools questioned whether the desegregation of schools and American educational institutions would realize the goal of providing quality education to all students, including good curricula, teachers, and economic mobility. To that end, these schools helped teach resistance and strategies of protest, and fought for improvements in conventional classrooms when the summer ended. Data feminism aims to examine and push back against power relationships in data science while embracing the multitude of perspectives involved in creating data settings. In many of the chapters, the authors discuss employees using collective action to pressure their employers. By teaching students strategies of resistance and protest, they can be more equipped in upholding these tenets of examining and challenging power in data feminism. I also think the goals of pluralism and prioritization of local perspectives in data feminism could be accomplished by creating new curricula with community engagement. This would help to examine and incorporate these local perspectives into how data science is taught in the future, similar to how Freedom Schools questioned demanded improvements to existing curricula.
Question: How can we best incorporate local, marginalized, and Indigenous perspectives in the creation of the goals and curricula of Freedom Schools?

zerver_message.subject: Lab Meeting Reflections
zerver_message.content:
Freedom Schools were designed to provide educational opportunities for African American Children and young adults who were denied access to quality education in the segregated South.  We should note that even though Freedom Schools were temporary and were not able to overcame the systemic problems of segregation in the South,  they were also successful in many ways. For example, they provided opportunities for thousands of African American Children and young adults, and they helped to inspire a new generation of civil rights activists.

The achievements of Freedom Schools has an intersection with the argument that Cathy O'Neil brings up in her article "Data Feminism," as she argues that data can be used to perpetuate gender inequality. She proposes a number of ways to make data more feminist, including rethinking the way we collect data, using more inclusive datasets, being more transparent about our methods, and challenging the status quo. Therefore, there is a clear path that we adopt to teach data feminism by adopting the freedom school strategy. For example, if we can create schools that provides students with the opportunity to learn about the history of data collection and analysis, as well as the ways in which data can be used to perpetuate gender inequality. Besides that, these schools could also provide students with the opportunity to develop their own data analysis skills, and to use these skills to challenge the status quo and create a more just and equitable society.

Question: Do you think that a different approach to the Freedom Schools could have been more successful? If so, what would that approach have been?

I spent a considerable amount of time trying to navigate through the various sections of the Visual Studio Code window, only to realize that the kernel selection was located at the top right corner. However, attending office hours proved to be immensely valuable as I received valuable assistance. I've always had reservations about using Visual Studio Code, as in a previous semester, I opted to code in the Emacs editor via the terminal instead of downloading and setting up VS Code. Nevertheless, I'm delighted that with Jaan's incredible guidance, I was able to navigate the instructions and visualize my progress.

zerver_message.subject: Lab Meeting Reflections
zerver_message.content:
I found as a read the article on Freedom Schools, that a lot of what was being advocated for in the reading was being done.  Though it was not defined as co-liberation that is exactly what the college students apart of SNCC and core were doing.  They politicized the right to education as much as they did the right to vote.  Looking back now it is easy to see how they are intertwine.  They also felt that education had the need to teach students how to "be organized to work on the society to change it,".  As the article said a lot  of the solutions we are looking for can be found in the ways that they protested and fought for better.  As we look to educate in data feminism we should also look to this.

As I have previously stated they didn't define their work as co-liberation but it was what they sought.  Though in they were able to champion integration to all fifty states they also pointed to how they felt integration was not necessarily the goal.  This in many ways reflected the belief of Data feminism to not assimilate or try to work within the system but to radically change it.  It was inspiring that students not only chose to help register disenfranchised voters but also teach the art of resistance and strategies of protest that helped raise questions about the very nature of American democracy.  This is exactly what data feminism seeks to do.  Co-liberation is grounded in the belief of enduring asymmetrical power that causes many societal problems.  As we seek to educate on data feminism and center this for of data justice we can look to this means of education to radically change the way we think about and work with it.

Another part of data feminism is embracing pluralism.  This is to say that a range of particpant should contribute their knowledge.  What the book points out is that a lot of times we don't consider whose values are lost and whose are imposed in the process of data analysis.  Places like Freedom Schools allowed for the marginalized children of the school system to be able to be heard and encouraged.  Some felt that this was a better education and never went back to traditional schools.  Others returned to schools in the fall but demanded more.  we should encourage plurality of outcomes from a shared starting place.  Data feminism could learn from the implementation of radicalizing change and what equity means.  In doing so it gives free rein for the people that have learned it to be able to employ it in different ways.

zerver_message.subject: Final Project
zerver_message.content:
My final project was a rushed job about:

*I try answer the following research question: "What are the differences in bike usage patterns between male and female smart bike users in Tartu?" With the increasing emphasis on sustainable modes of transport, understanding user demographics and behaviours is crucial in shaping policies and systems that cater to the needs of diverse user groups. My interest in this topic arises from the observation that gender dynamics in urban mobility are often overlooked, potentially leading to skewed services, that may not fully cater to all demographics.

The findings of this research could provide valuable insights to city planners and transportation providers. If significant differences are found, it could indicate a need to revise the smart bike services to make them more inclusive and accessible to all users. This could result in improved user experience, increased usage of smart bikes, and consequently, progress towards the environmental goals of reducing carbon emissions and promoting healthier lifestyles.*

Blog post (for now, might edit more later) is here: https://github.com/ikr503/blog.datathinking.org/blob/IndrekBlogPost/indrekBlogPost.md

zerver_message.subject: experience reports
zerver_message.content: My experience report: I had trouble setting up my virtual environment. I’ve had issues with VSCode in the past, especially with regards to installing libraries and packages. One problem is that I have 3 different versions of VSCode on my computer with different libraries installed on each one. While trying to visualize the data, I ran into problems as chatGPT’s suggestions did not work and had to spend time trying to debug instead. Knowing that other people were struggling with setup as well and having someone who I could share error messages with helped. Going over our work from the last 2 weeks, I found it interesting to think about how my own assumptions and beliefs drive how I interact with technology.

zerver_message.subject: experience reports
zerver_message.content: My experience report: Engaging with these new tools and code was very intimidating, especially trying to tackle the instructions on my own. I expected this feeling as this area is unfamiliar to me. The first obstacle was trying to get the student development pack verified. After finally figuring out the VPN issue, I still did not receive a confirmation of approval. After multiple attempts and a lot of feelings of overwhelm and stress, I decided to reach out and attend 1-1 office hours with Jaan. Through this office hour and the guidance of Jaan, it was easier to be more patient with myself, break down instructions given, navigate new tools, and troubleshoot when things didn't run smoothly. Having the guidance of the instructor the assignment seems a lot less intimidating and easier to tackle. Similarly to what Jalynn said, I did not know that my laptop had something called a terminal. The hardest part for me was understanding specific vocabulary and navigating new tools ie. knowing what buttons to click, where to find files etc.
